results.title: Night driving
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, John Edwards and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “How to Drive”.
If your vision is normal and the lighting equipment of your car is in efficient working order, there is nothing to be scared of in night driving. The same section of road from a driver’s viewpoint is shown by day and by night, pointing out the different methods of detecting various features which will affect course and speed in night driving.

results.title: Night and fog = Nuit et brouillard
results.brief_description: Commissioned to mark the tenth anniversary of the concentration camps’ liberation, “Nuit et Brouillard” (English title “Night and Fog”)is one of the most respected documentaries in world cinema. From the post-war ruins of Auschwitz, seen in elegiac colour, to its horrifying past, recorded in stark black and white, Resnais’ film pursues the question which still haunts us today: do we share the guilt for those deported, tortured and killed? Jean Cayrol’s moving commentary challenges us not to forget, to “look around and hear people crying endlessly?” For a few hours, the film wipes out the memory of all other films. It must be seen. Features photography by two of France’s most renowned cinematographers, Ghislain Cloquet and Sacha Vierny. Music by Hanns Eisler, assistant director Chris Marker.

results.title: Nigeria 1960 - sunrise in the east
results.creator_credit: Andre Libik, Victor M. Gover, British Information Services and Eric Chamberlain
results.brief_description: A survey of eastern Nigeria against a background of Independence celebrations: the region and its people, natural resources and recent developments in industry, agriculture, transport, communications, health and education services.

results.title: Nigeria's University College
results.creator_credit: Nigerian Film Unit and Lionel Snazelle

results.title: Nicky: one of my best friends
results.creator_credit: Togg Films, McGraw-Hill Films, Grania Gurievitch and Anthony Jones
results.brief_description: Nicky is a blind boy who also suffers from cerebral palsy. This film shows him at home with his family and at school with his friends. Nicky attends a normal school because his parents feel that he would benefit more by being in the mainstream.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: war and the fall of the Czar, 1914-1917
results.creator_credit: Sam Spiegel, Franklin J. Schaffner and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Shows the intertwining of Russia’s war policy abroad with her chaos at home. Tells how Nicholas went to the front with the army, leaving Alexandra to rule and how she thought only of her son’s possible cure. Ends with Czar’s abdication. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: the Bolshevik Victory, 1917
results.creator_credit: Sam Spiegel, Franklin J. Schaffner and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Covers the October Revolution and shows the radicalisation, counter revolution and civil war. Explains that Lenin returned to Russia, promising peace and a new socialist order. Shows how Kerensky became powerless and ends with the Czar’s execution. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman, Jack Hawkins, Ian Holm to tell the story of the Bolshevik victory.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: prelude to revolution, 1904-1905
results.creator_credit: Sam Spiegel, Franklin J. Schaffner and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Focuses on the years 1904-1905. Shows some of the causes of the Russian revolution that were visible more than a decade before Lenin arrived at the Finland station. Reveals the extreme contrasts of Russia, the role of the Czar, the workers, the revolutionaries and the peasants. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman, Laurence Olivier.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra
results.creator_credit: Armorer Wason, Granite Film, Granada International Productions and Michael Beckham
results.brief_description: For over 70 years the story of Russia’s last Tsar, Nicholas II and his Empress, Alexandra has exercised a poignant magic. Presented by His Royal Highness Prince Michael of Kent, this documentary delves into the imperial archives held in Moscow and St Petersberg, once sealed by the Secret Police and forbidden to all but a handful of curators. The archives reveal intimate diaries and letters of the Romanovs, their photograph albums, records of state visits and political intrigue.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Armorer Wason, Granite Film, Granada International Productions and Michael Beckham

results.title: Nice time
results.brief_description: An observation of couples and youths at night around London’s famous Piccadilly Circus. Influenced by the Free Cinema movement, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner allow the camera to observe the scenes of people milling in front of cinemas, walking around the Circle and attempting to get into night clubs. There is no voice over, and instead, it is the observational mise-en-scene and the almost relaxed detachment of the observing camera that creates a leisurely but intriguing glimpse into everyday pleasure and life. The decision of the Swiss directors, Goretta and Tanner, to travel to the UK to involve themselves in Free Cinema was an indication of the immense influence the movement was having on documentary filmmaking, an influence that was to lead to the radical aesthetics of “cinema verite”.
